BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2000 m.
Avalanches can be released and reach large size in isolated cases. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as on wind-loaded slopes above approximately 2000 m. From starting zones that have retained some snow in these regions the avalanches can in isolated cases still reach an unusually long way.
At low and intermediate altitudes moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 100 to 150 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last four days above approximately 2000 m. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions.
The sleet gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of Easter Sunday remain in some cases prone to triggering in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes. As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs formed. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye.

As a consequence of warming during the day moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 2900 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are still not entirely ruled out. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2200 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Numerous medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released until Monday, 1 April.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly in all altitude zones.
Until Monday the weather will be very mild. On Saturday it will be very warm.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of Easter Sunday remain in some cases prone to triggering in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes. As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs formed. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye.

As a consequence of warming during the day moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 2900 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are still not entirely ruled out. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.

60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2200 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Numerous medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released until Monday, 1 April.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly in all altitude zones.
Until Monday the weather will be very mild. On Saturday it will be very warm.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye.

As a consequence of warming during the day moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 2900 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are still not entirely ruled out. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2100 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow.
5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Wednesday.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Several medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Tuesday.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly in all altitude zones.
Until Monday the weather will be very mild. On Saturday it will be very warm.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye.

As a consequence of warming during the day moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 2900 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are still not entirely ruled out. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2100 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow.
5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Wednesday.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Several medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Tuesday.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly in all altitude zones.
Until Monday the weather will be very mild. On Saturday it will be very warm.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain large wind slabs formed. Dry avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases and reach large size. Below approximately 2300 m medium-sized to large ground avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall gave rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In addition the more recent wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions, but the avalanche danger will increase later. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible. From early morning the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.
Avalanches can be released and reach large size in isolated cases, especially in high Alpine regions.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 1600 m rain has fallen in some regions. As a consequence of rising temperatures and rain up to intermediate altitudes the snowpack settled during the last few days.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The wind slabs of the last few days are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack on near-ridge shady slopes and in high Alpine regions.
Since yesterday the weather has been mild. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften earlier than the day before, especially at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of warming the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a wet old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area continuous warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of warming the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a wet old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area continuous warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at elevated altitudes. Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in some cases be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can release the wet old snow as well.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded still only poorly together.

Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase.
As a consequence of rising temperatures the snow drift accumulations will stabilise.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A critical avalanche situation will persist in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible.
New snow and wind slabs can be released and reach medium size, especially in high Alpine regions.
The current avalanche situation calls for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at elevated altitudes. Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in some cases be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can release the wet old snow as well.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded still only poorly together.

Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase.
As a consequence of rising temperatures the snow drift accumulations will stabilise.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach medium size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
Backcountry tours should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen in particular in the Prealps.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs formed. The wind slabs are lying on a crust in high Alpine regions.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach medium size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
Backcountry tours should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen in particular in the Prealps.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs formed. The wind slabs are lying on a crust in high Alpine regions.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften earlier than the day before. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. On sunny slopes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area continuous warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on steep sunny slopes at high altitude, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good in some case. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack in shady places that are protected from the wind below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The moist fresh snow of the last few days and the deep wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, especially on steep sunny slopes at high altitude, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good in some case. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1900 m: In gullies and bowls mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes.
